title: DataScienceHW1
text:
1. What do you think being a data scientist is about?
I believe that being a data scientist is about shaping data and identifying patterns and other insights from this data in order to support a wide variety of fields of study.
2. What differences/similarities do you see between data scientists and statisticians?
I believe that statistics is the foundation of data science. Therefore, I believe that statisticians do the ‘behind-the-scenes’ work first and then data scientists manipulate the data produced by statisticians to identify insights.
3. How do you view yourself in relation to these two areas?
I am an operations research analyst by trade, so I view my work as very similar to that of data scientists. I do not view myself as a statistician as I know that statistics is not my strongest area of expertise.

title: DataScienceHW1
text:
Code Test

y <- density(iris$Sepal.Length)


# Determine the class of the object y
class_y <- class(y)

# Determine the type of the object y
type_y <- typeof(y)

# Determine the structure of the object y
str(y)

List of 7
 $ x        : num [1:512] 3.48 3.49 3.5 3.51 3.52 ...
 $ y        : num [1:512] 0.000232 0.000262 0.000296 0.000333 0.000373 ...
 $ bw       : num 0.274
 $ n        : int 150
 $ call     : language density.default(x = iris$Sepal.Length)
 $ data.name: chr "iris$Sepal.Length"
 $ has.na   : logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "density"

title: DataScienceHW1
text:
Markdown Test
In the code chunk above, I utilized the class(), typeof(), and str() functions to, respectively, determine the class, type, and structure of the object y.
In the code chunk below, I utilized the plot() function to plot the object y. I also set the echo chunk object to false in order to hide the R code in the final, documented output.
